ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Asynchronous lectures and student presentations, individual film screenings

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: None; I learned absolutely nothing in this class. I picked up a couple of German words like "polizei" (police), "angst" (fear), and "frau" (woman). So I guess I learned about police, fear, and women.

I learned about German film from 1945-2020, with a significant focus on films of the twenty first century. I also developed skills in film analysis, reading film theory, and more generally considering trends in both German history and German cinema.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Weaknesses:
- Pretentious and shallow discussion by students who are clearly disinterested in engaging with their peers.
- Lots of Professors' Pets who laugh at everything Fatima says and smile really close to the camera.
- Professor did little to foster a sense of community.
- Half the class never spoke.

Strengths: diverse films introduce students to an expansive array of history, culture, and methods of storytelling.

Strengths: Professor Naqvi was a thoughtful and engaging discussion leader, and I thought all the films we viewed were valuable and interesting for a variety of reasons. 

Weaknesses: While this class was very immersive, it was difficult to keep track of all the elements we needed to watch or view before seminar every week, which could sometimes include multiple lecture, 1-2 student presentations, multiple readings, and multiple films. It could get overwhelming at times to juggle all of those moving parts within an online setting.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Asynchronous lectures were helpful, but they were rather long and made for HOURS of video watching per week. Splitting into English/German discussion rooms was cool, but I never got to discuss with half of the class.

Succeeded: It was easy to watch the films offline and Professor Naqvi ensured it was simple to access them. Breakout rooms during seminar ran smoothly. 

Could be improved: It would have been easier to juggle less asynchronous materials week-to-week, as the sheer amount of content we had to consume to get a bit overwhelming at times.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No. You could just as easily watch the films on your own. Your only hope is a group of students better than the one I had. This course is in my top 3 biggest regrets at Yale.

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in German cinema (or cinema more generally). The topics are certainly fascinating, and it's a good introduction to film if you've never taken a film course before.
